title: 115_s317
content: The "Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act" is the short title of this Act. It includes a provision for an inventory of government programs. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act includes an amendment to Section 1122(a) of title 31, United States Code, defining a program as an organized set of activities by one or more agencies directed toward a common purpose or goal. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is responsible for maintaining a website and program inventory. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act amends Section 1122(a) of title 31, United States Code to define a program as an organized set of activities with a common purpose. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must maintain a website with a program inventory listing federal programs with over $1,000,000 in annual budget authority. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act amends Section 1122(a) of title 31, United States Code to define a program as an organized set of activities with a common purpose. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must maintain a website with a program inventory listing federal programs with over $1,000,000 in annual budget authority. The Act requires detailed information on each program, including competitive financial awards and activities referenced in law as a program after June 30, 2019. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act requires detailed information on federal programs with over $10,000,000 in annual budget authority. This includes identifying program activities, funding amounts for the current and previous two fiscal years. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act mandates detailed information on federal programs with over $10,000,000 in annual budget authority, including program activities, funding amounts for the current and previous two fiscal years, identification of statutes authorizing the program, major regulations, and descriptions of individuals served and beneficiaries receiving financial assistance. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act requires detailed information on federal programs with over $10,000,000 in annual budget authority, including program activities, funding amounts, statutes authorizing the program, regulations, and descriptions of individuals served and beneficiaries. Additionally, it mandates providing estimates of individuals and beneficiaries served by each program, with explanations if data is not available and measures to gather the required data. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act mandates detailed information on federal programs with over $10,000,000 in annual budget authority, including program activities, funding amounts, statutes, regulations, and descriptions of individuals served and beneficiaries. It also requires a description of Federal employees and other individuals whose salary is paid by the Federal Government and assist in administering the program. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act requires detailed information on federal programs with over $10,000,000 in annual budget authority, including program activities, funding amounts, statutes, regulations, and descriptions of individuals served and beneficiaries. It also mandates disclosure of Federal employees and others involved in program administration, evaluation reports, and financial information as per the Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act requires detailed information on federal programs with annual budget authority between $1,000,000 and $10,000,000, including program activities, funding amounts, statutes, and regulations. The Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act mandates detailed information on federal programs with annual budget authority between $1,000,000 and $10,000,000, including program activities, funding amounts, statutes, and regulations. The program inventory must include descriptions of individuals served, beneficiaries receiving financial assistance, and links to evaluations or performance reviews released in the past 5 years, archived annually by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. Authorization of Appropriations: $18,000,000 is authorized for the Director of the Office of Management and Budget for fiscal years 2018, 2019, and 2020 to implement the Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act and its amendments. SEC. 3. GUIDANCE, IMPLEMENTATION, REPORTING, AND REVIEW. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is required to prescribe initial guidance for implementing the Act, issue guidance to agencies for program reporting, and may provide additional guidance to ensure program identification. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is responsible for ensuring that programs identified in the program inventory are presented consistently across agencies and not duplicative. They may also extend implementation deadlines and exempt agencies from certain requirements under title 31, United States Code. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is responsible for ensuring program consistency and non-duplication across agencies. Agencies with budget authority under $10,000,000 and not listed in section 901(b) of title 31, United States Code, may be exempt from certain requirements. The Act and its amendments must be implemented by June 30, 2019. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to Congress within 5 years of the Act's enactment on its implementation. The Act requires a review of program activities by the Office of Management and Budget and agencies to determine what constitutes a program. It also evaluates the usefulness of the program inventory in decision-making and coherence in depicting Federal involvement. The Comptroller's recommendations are included in the evaluation. The Act mandates a review of program activities by the Office of Management and Budget and agencies to define programs. It assesses the program inventory's utility in decision-making and coherence in showing Federal involvement, including the Comptroller General's recommendations. The Senate and House committees will conduct hearings to review the report's findings.
